title: Can payroll taxes & workers comp taxes be discharged in bankruptcy?
question: i owe workers comp from 2011 & over $80k of payroll taxes from last qrter of 2011. will filing bankruptcy dicharge them? how about unpaid wages with the interest & penalties. last day empaloyees worked was 6 months ago.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Workers' compensation,Employee wages and payroll taxes,Employee wages and wage theft
answers: You may also want to talk to a lawyer who handles criminal defense as well. Failure to pay those taxes may have been a criminal act.

As the other post indicates, the payroll taxes are not dischargeable, but payment could be stretched out over 5 years in a Chapter 13 or Chapter 11 case. Unpaid wages likely are dischargeable. I'd need more information on the workers compensation to render an opinion on that.

Your workers comp insurance is a dischargeable debt. The "trust fund" portion of payroll taxes (taken from the employee's check) are not. However, the employer matching portion of the payroll can be discharged. You may be in a position to do a Chapter 7 bankruptcy to rid yourself of the general dischargeable debts, then do a Chapter 13 to control the payment of the trust fund taxes.

Lots of issues here. And the information you list suggests you MUST speak to a competent attorney for doing anything.

The short and general answers (and theses I not mete out in your situation) are as follows:

The payroll taxes are not dischargeable. They are a claim related to funds that were not lent to you, but which actually belong to someone else (hence why they are called trust fund taxes ). The best bankruptcy can do is pay them over time.

The wages are, up to a certain amount, a priority unsecured tax - the priority status changing how they are completed.

The comp claims are something you'll need to speak to a lawyer about as different states qualify their comp fees differently (a tax for Some states, an insurance payment for others).

Good luck!
